11.53.text:
It's funny because my speech

We nearly did, because I just had hiccups

26.01.text:
the most important relationship
we have in our lives

28.85.text:
is the one we have with ourselves
and we are not taught about it.

33.33.text: I want to challenge you to think about

35.76.text:
if we were taught how to look
after ourselves using self-care,

40.36.text:
could we help enrich our lives,
make us happier,

43.75.text:
combat our insecurities and enable us

48.72.text:
For example, have you
ever blamed your body?

It's because I put on

66.62.text:
body image is often associated

69.89.text:
But in fact, men and boys

73.19.text:
Eating disorders and mental health
can affect anyone

75.85.text: at any age, at any time.

78.67.text: And that's why this is so important to me

80.98.text:
and why we are here today
connecting with you all.

83.97.text:
So many guys now are going to the gym
and they're even abusing steroids,

88.64.text:
because maybe their selfies
would get more likes

90.90.text: if they had a six pack of abs, not beer.

94.94.text:
I know that when I was younger,
I would look in that mirror

98.67.text:
every single day,
and hate what I saw.

102.31.text: "Why don't I have a thigh gap?"

104.36.text:
"Why does it look like
this thigh ate the other one?"

107.76.text:
"Ugh, more pimples?
Are you kidding me?"

114.27.text: because I can't get those years back

of self-loathing,

So I decided to use those
experiences that I've had,

123.82.text:
to gain a better understanding
of the relationship I have

129.37.text:
And by practicing self-care,
I was able to change my life.

133.68.text:
I hope, today, I can encourage you all,
If you haven't already started,

138.05.text: to start that journey of self-love.

143.69.text:
We have so many pressures,
and now we have social media.

147.16.text:
With the rise of social media,
we literary have

150.00.text:
a weapon of mass destruction
to our self-esteem 24/7.

155.16.text: You guys, you consume social media.

157.17.text:
Have you ever lost one, two,
maybe even three hours of your life,

165.96.text:
Thinking, "Oh, wow, look,
they're so in love."

168.75.text:
"Oh, they're going to all these
amazing holidays!"

171.28.text:
"They have the dream job!
They have this perfect life!"

177.22.text: The scary thing is, that's not real.

180.55.text:
Social media is a curated,
filtered, often airbrushed,

189.91.text: That's why we need to be taught about it.

192.10.text:
That is why we need
to be taught how to cope

196.30.text:
And it's become my mission,
to teach self-care

199.35.text: and get it into the education system.

201.70.text:
Because we need to be taught
how to look after ourselves

207.11.text:
I'm very grateful; I have
over three million followers online

210.45.text:
and I commit to being authentic,
honest with them,

213.25.text:
and not retouching my pictures that I own,
because I have to forgive myself.

218.20.text: I've been in the industry for 13 years.

221.13.text: And I would get images back of myself

223.25.text:
that my family couldn't even recognize me
when they flipped through the magazine.

228.72.text: I would look at these pictures and think,

230.75.text:
"Oh, wow! Where did half of my arms go?
My legs are so much skinnier!"

236.60.text: "Is that how I'm meant to look?"

238.48.text: "I'm meant to be that perfected image?"

241.26.text:
"Wow! Well, I can't even
look like that and that's me!"

247.85.text:
So, why is it that we feel
these insecurities in the first place?

252.04.text:
Because from a very young age,
we've been conditioned to believe

255.88.text:
that our success and our happiness
is highly dependent on our attractiveness.

261.58.text:
Think about all the prince
and princesses you saw:

268.55.text:
The magazines - and celebrating severe
weight loss that's actually unhealthy.

273.46.text:
Or those who have been nipped
and tucked to look 20 years younger.

277.14.text:
Because if we are insecure,
we are a motivated consumer.

282.50.text:
We can be sold an anti-wrinkle
cream by a 13 year old,

286.53.text:
a push-up bra that looks
absolutely ridiculous,

289.15.text:
because I've been on set years ago,
where they were actually wearing a bra

293.42.text:
under the bra to give
unattainable cleavage.

297.69.text: Yeah, that happens, so do butt-pads.

300.67.text:
The butt-pads are in all those
jean adverts you see, just saying.

308.61.text:
by the National Eating Disorders
Association of the US,

311.78.text:
whom I'm an ambassador for,
and something called "The Body Project."

317.25.text:
to help prevent eating disorders
in young people.

322.14.text:
the impact on these pupils
was outstanding,

325.05.text:
and it confirmed to me
that we need to be talking about this.

328.51.text:
So I thought I'd shared with you
some of that today.

331.72.text:
The main concept we teach
is the "beauty ideal myth."

336.11.text:
We get all the kids to have magazines
and they pick out the perfect body

340.67.text: We then break it down for them.

342.34.text: "OK, so what's the perfect body then?"

344.34.text: "Well, it's tall, big boobs, small waist,

346.99.text:
or it's ridiculous abs,
it's a tan, straight hair, no flaws."

356.81.text:
So what are the sacrifices and costs
for you to try and attain this?

360.99.text:
It's so detrimental to your mental
and physical health.

368.18.text:
The brands, the magazines,
the pharmaceutical industry.

375.59.text:
So, we need to embrace
our bodies for more than that.

379.67.text:
We need to stop trying
to attain perfection,

381.94.text: because we are good enough already.

384.24.text:
If we could start redefining
the beauty ideal,

391.15.text:
their accomplishments, their personality,
their morals and their values.

398.16.text:
I recently was challenged
to get three women,

402.40.text:
who would have refused
to ever be in a bikini,

405.36.text:
to go in a bikini, live on national TV,
in front of three million people

409.95.text:
and on the streets of London
in front of crowds.

413.61.text:
These were women who -
I generally talk to kind of school kids -

417.98.text: There was a lady in her 70s,

419.90.text:
who had recently lost
her partner and had excess skin.

423.53.text:
There was another lady, who was a mother
and she'd had an eating disorder

427.02.text:
and really struggled
with body image her whole life.

429.76.text:
The other woman had been horrifically
body-shamed by an ex-partner.

434.06.text:
So, we go backstage and I'm like,
"OK, I hope I can do this."

438.17.text: They call me and they're like,

439.60.text:
"Iskra, you need to get
in the changing room right now.

444.74.text:
They stuck three women in a room
with one mirror and five bikinis and said,

448.68.text:
"You must choose one of these
and you're going to go out there in it."

452.39.text: Come on, that's a lot of pressure.

454.79.text: So, I went in there and taught them

457.95.text:
one of my biggest areas of self-care,
which I call my "mirror challenge."

462.85.text:
Initially, they're standing
in that mirror; the first thing they do -

466.17.text:
and I'm sure many of you do as well -
is see your insecurities.

470.08.text: We need to change that discussion.

472.55.text:
So, I get them in front of the mirror
in their bikinis, and I tell them,

476.63.text:
"Pick out five things
that you love about yourself."

479.95.text:
I gave them a few examples
and they started.

483.27.text: "Well, I'm the life of the party."

487.41.text:
"I'm creative, I'm independent,
I'm hard-working, I'm courageous."

492.49.text:
Then they started thinking,
"Ooh, I'm pretty cool!"

496.17.text: They started feeling proud of themselves.

499.19.text:
Then I told them,
"Now, pick out five things

501.46.text:
that you love about your body
for what it does for you."

504.46.text:
Because we want to change that discussion,
not just about what your body looks like.

508.41.text: Your body is an incredible thing.

510.01.text:
So, they started saying ...
it was so inspiring for me as well.

513.24.text:
because you never know
what people are going to come up with.

518.87.text:
even though I'm really insecure
about them, they enabled me.

522.60.text:
This stomach enabled me
to birth my children,

525.25.text:
and now I have grandchildren,
and that's the best part of my life."

529.43.text:
Another woman said,
"I'm grateful for these hands,

531.99.text:
because I was able to be a seamstress,
and provide for my whole family."

536.29.text: The last woman said, "Well, I love my legs

539.01.text:
because I love running
through the English countryside;

541.81.text:
it calms me down,
and it's what makes me happy."

548.90.text: They were so proud of themselves.

551.31.text: I then proceeded to tell them

552.74.text:
that not only is it going
to change their life,

555.57.text:
being able to embrace their bodies,
and go out there and be confident,

558.90.text:
but the women and men at home,
who feel just the way they did,

563.38.text: it's going to help them too.

565.23.text:
For them to stand up there
and be able to do it,

567.49.text:
it's hopefully going
to empower them as well.

570.50.text:
I still didn't 100 percent know
if they were going to do it,

573.40.text:
but we go out there,
right by the Thames in London,

576.59.text:
and sure enough,
all three dropped their robes.

579.41.text: There was tears; there was hugging,

582.16.text:
two of the women didn't even
put their robes back on.

584.66.text:
They went all the way straight
through the TV show,

587.06.text: back up to the dressing room,

588.45.text:
were like, "Well, here I am now,
I'm doing it, so I'm not going back!"

594.70.text:
I never felt so purposeful,
so filled with hope.

599.78.text:
That's why I'm so excited
to be here with you today

603.94.text:
That's one of my main ways
that I practice self-care.

607.92.text: The next one is called "a gratitude list."

611.65.text:
I have an example; 
I had to use it not that long ago,

615.43.text:
I was in LA with my boyfriend,
and we went shopping.

619.13.text:
We went to the store, and I saw
these gorgeous designer jeans,

622.55.text:
and I was like, 
"OK, I'm going to treat myself."

625.32.text:
So, the store associate said,
"What size are you?"

628.04.text:
I said, "Hmm, like a 12. I don't know
what that is, maybe a 31."

631.84.text:
And she goes, "Well, the biggest
size we have is this one,

634.58.text: and it's a 29, but it's so stretchy.

636.95.text:
It's definitely going to fit.
Everyone fits in it."

640.49.text:
I go in the changing room,
which is the worst place in the world.

644.13.text:
A: It's claustrophobic as hell,
it's usually hot,

647.07.text:
the lighting is from above,
the mirror is just awful,

649.63.text:
and then it feels like 
your inner demons are there

654.49.text:
So, I'm in there with these jeans
and it's like me against the jeans.

657.79.text:
And I'm there, and I'm like,
"OK, it's not going well."

661.87.text:
Then she's shouting in,
"I bet they look so good!"

667.40.text: And I kind of got to here, and I was like,

669.74.text: "Iskra, you just have to give up."

675.70.text: That 15-year-old me came back and said,

678.47.text: "You're unworthy of being in these jeans.

680.97.text: "You're too big. What's wrong with you?"

684.28.text:
"Why can't you fit into the biggest
pair of jeans in the store?"

689.18.text:
"Come on, Iskra, come on!
Use that self-care, go, go, go!"

691.95.text: I brought out my gratitude list.

693.89.text:
I want you all to start your own
right now, tonight.

697.11.text: Because it saved me in that moment.

699.64.text:
"Wow, OK, I'm on holiday;
I have a real boyfriend,

703.06.text:
who loves me at this size,
so clearly, that's good."

708.18.text:
"I'm in LA, I'm from England,
that's awesome."

710.94.text:
"I'm healthy, I'm alive,
I have clean water."

714.38.text:
And then I started to think,
"What the hell?

717.10.text:
These jeans right here,
this piece of fabric

719.50.text: is trying to break me right now.

721.36.text: These are not going to ruin my day.

723.34.text:
I refuse, flat out refuse to let this
ruin how I feel about myself."

728.75.text:
So I used that self-care, that knowledge;
thank god I had that.

732.60.text:
because otherwise, I would have
gone out there, a blubbering mess,

735.70.text:
and my boyfriend would ask,
"What's wrong with you?"

738.52.text:
That is my other piece
of self-care I'm giving to you.

741.43.text:
If we go back, the reason
why this can seem shallow to some maybe,

749.06.text:
is because there is some
shocking statistics out there.

751.86.text: Did you know, as a teenage girl,

754.46.text:
you are 12 times more likely
to die from an eating disorder,

760.17.text: That there are over 30 million of us,

762.22.text:
in the US alone,
that have an eating disorder.

765.22.text:
And that 90% from all children
who die from suicide

771.49.text:
As I mentioned earlier,
social media is only growing.

777.11.text:
And 52% of US teens now say
they have been cyber-bullied.

781.77.text:
I have experienced, first-hand,
hate online, trolling online.

786.02.text:
We also need to talk about that.
That to me is also part of self-care.

792.68.text:
are just putting their insecurities
that they have onto you.

796.69.text:
I know that when someone says something
nasty about me, it's a reflection

800.13.text: of how they are feeling inside.

801.97.text:
But we need to educate people,
educate the victims and the bullies,

808.66.text:
One way I like to do it is:
ignore it, report it, block it,

812.41.text: delete it, act like it never happened.

814.99.text: But I found another cool way.

817.59.text:
I recently got a comment,
and for me, it was hysterical,

821.50.text:
but a few of my followers
got really upset about it,

823.95.text:
because they said, "You're the reason
that the healthcare system is a mess.

827.58.text:
You need to put down your McDonald's
and stop eating crisps."

832.82.text:
I happen to be on set in my underwear,
doing a shoot with crisps around me,

837.76.text:
"Hmm, this seems like a good opportunity
to show them what I'm made of."

842.36.text:
So, I decided to do a picture of me
covered in crisps, eating the crisps,

848.72.text:
like "Hell no! Are you going
to bring me down?

851.46.text:
I'm going to keep eating crisps
even more now actually,

854.08.text: I really really like crisps now."

859.54.text:
I wanted to be able to use
something that was negative

862.09.text: and turn it into a positive.

863.44.text:
Sure enough, I think that video
got like 18 million views or something

866.73.text:
because that's what we want to see;
we want to build each other up.

870.08.text: We want to empower each other.

872.04.text:
I'm so grateful I've been here today,
and been able to connect with you all,

876.21.text:
because I want to encourage
every single one of you

878.81.text: to invest in yourself right now.

882.36.text:
I want you to understand
that if you learn self-care,

885.91.text:
practice self-care,
you can then gift self-care.

889.69.text:
Imagine being able to give
your loved ones the gift of self-love.

894.95.text: Speak to your body in a loving way.

897.03.text: It's the only one you've got,

898.43.text:
it's your home,
and it deserves your respect.

901.74.text:
If you see anyone tearing
themselves down, build them back up.

906.53.text: And watch your life positively grow

908.66.text:
when you give up
the pursuit of perfection.

911.53.text:
Because the real beauty ideal
is being imperfectly you.
